key_mistakes.reason: White develops the knight but misses an opportunity to control the center more effectively.
White develops the bishop but misses further central control.
This move allows White to gain a significant advantage by capturing the pawn.
This move allows Black to equalize more easily.
Misses a tactical opportunity to capture the knight.
This move loses tempo and doesn't address the immediate threats.
Fails to capture the hanging pawn, allowing Black to maintain pressure.
Castling into a potential attack and losing material.
Captures a pawn but misses a stronger queen move maintaining central control.
Misses the opportunity to activate the rook effectively.
Does not improve the position significantly and wastes a move.
Moves the knight away from the center without a clear plan.
Exchanges a well-placed knight for a pawn, losing control of key squares.
Misses a chance to create counterplay on the queenside.
This move allows Black to immediately threaten a decisive attack.
Allows for a forced checkmate sequence.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center in the opening phase.
Avoid unnecessary pawn moves that weaken your position.
Prioritize piece activity and coordination over material gains.
Be aware of tactical opportunities and threats, especially when the opponent's king is exposed.
